Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The phone pressed to my ear, I rattled off the latest promotion, my script flowing as smoothly as the numbers on my sales sheet. I was already ahead of my quota—management would be pleased. But as I prepared to dial the next number, the building’s alarm blared, shrill and urgent. Through the window, I saw water pooling in the street, swirling higher with every second. The emergency alert on my phone flashed: flash-flood warning, evacuate immediately. My manager’s words echoed in my mind: “Every call counts, don’t lose momentum.” But as a citizen, I knew what was expected—help others, ensure safety, follow evacuation orders. My neighbor, an elderly woman, lived alone down the hall. Should I keep calling, riding the wave of my sales streak, or drop everything to check on her and help others evacuate? My heart pounded, torn between the demands of my job and my responsibility to my community, the phone heavy in my hand as the water crept closer.
